OBSERVED:
- k5 = k2 × k3 (indices 2,3 → product 5×? no)
- k12 = k8 × 12 - 5 (index 12 appears in formula!)

HYPOTHESIS: Sometimes the INDEX itself appears in the formula.

CHECK:
1. k7 = ? × 7 + ? → 76/7 = 10.86 (not clean)
2. k8 = ? × 8 + ? → 224/8 = 28 = k8/8 ✓ (28 is integer!)
3. k9 = ? × 9 + ? → 467/9 = 51.89 (not clean)
4. k11 = ? × 11 + ? → 1155/11 = 105 (integer!)
5. k12 = ? × 12 + ? → 2683/12 = 223.58... but k8×12-5=2683

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Is there a pattern where k_n = f(n) × n + g(n)?

Calculate f(n) for each key.

I'll produce final answer accordingly.</think>We wish to “peel‐off” a factor from each key number by writing

  kₙ = f(n)·n + g(n).

In many puzzles one chooses the remainder (that is, g(n)) so that it lies between 0 and n–1; however, sometimes a different choice makes the answer “look nicer.” For example, we are told that

  k₁₂ = 2683 = k₈·12 – 5 = 224×12 – 5,

so one may choose to write
  f(12) = 224 and g(12) = –5,
even though if you divide 2683 by 12 in the usual way (with a nonnegative remainder less than 12) you would get

  2683 = 223×12 + 7 (with f(12)=223 and g(12)=7).

Below are two ways to “calculate” f(n) for the given keys.

───────────────────────────── 
Method 1. (Using the usual division algorithm so that 0 ≤ g(n) < n)

We know:
 k₇ = 76, k₈ = 224, k₉ = 467, k₁₁ = 1155.

Divide each by its index:

• For n = 7:
 76 ÷ 7 gives quotient 10 with remainder 6 (since 10×7 + 6 = 76).
 Thus, f(7) = 10.

• For n = 8:
 224 ÷ 8 = 28 exactly.
 So, f(8) = 28.

• For n = 9:
 467 divided by 9: 9×51 = 459 and 467 – 459 = 8,
 so f(9) = 51 (with g(9)=8).

• For n = 11:
 1155 ÷ 11 = 105 exactly.
 Thus, f(11) = 105.

• For n = 12:
 2683 divided by 12: 12×223 = 2676 with remainder 7,
 so one would take f(12)=223 (with g(12)=7).

───────────────────────────── 
Method 2. (Using a “nice” form suggested by the puzzle)

Notice that we are told explicitly that
 k₁₂ = 2683 = k₈·12 – 5 = 224×12 – 5.
That is, one may choose to represent k₁₂ as

 2683 = 224×12 + (–5).

In this representation the “multiplier” f(12) becomes 224. (The other keys remain unchanged:
 f(7)=10, f(8)=28, f(9)=51, f(11)=105.)

───────────────────────────── 
Which answer is “correct?” 

It depends on how one chooses to define the remainder. In many texts (by the Division Algorithm) one requires 0 ≤ g(n) < n so that f(n) and g(n) are uniquely determined. In that case you would have

 f(7)=10, f(8)=28, f(9)=51, f(11)=105, and f(12)=223.

However, since the puzzle highlights the form
 k₁₂ = k₈·12 – 5,
it is natural in this context to choose

 f(7)=10, f(8)=28, f(9)=51, f(11)=105, and f(12)=224
(with g(12) = –5).

───────────────────────────── 
Answer Summary

Either answer is acceptable depending on your convention. A complete answer might be stated as follows:

• Using the standard (nonnegative remainder) division:
  k₇ = 10·7 + 6 → f(7)=10,
  k₈ = 28·8 + 0 → f(8)=28,
  k₉ = 51·9 + 8 → f(9)=51,
  k₁₁ = 105·11 + 0 → f(11)=105,
  k₁₂ = 223·12 + 7 → f(12)=223.

• Or, if one prefers the “nice” form given by
  k₁₂ = k₈·12 – 5 = 224×12 – 5,
then one may take
  f(7)=10, f(8)=28, f(9)=51, f(11)=105, and f(12)=224.

Both answers are correct; the choice depends on whether you insist that the remainder be nonnegative or allow a negative one for aesthetic reasons.
